name: Radbug
text:
RADBUG was an Orc in the Tower of Cirith Ungol, who was killed by
Shagrat in the battle over Frodo's Mithril Shirt (apparently by
strangulation).

name: Asgon
text:
ASGON was a man of Dor-lómin.

He helped Túrin get out of Dor-lómin after he slew Brodda, the
Easterling and was probably part of a rebels band there.

name: Muzgash
text:
MUZGASH was an Orc of Cirith Ungol. Biography Muzgash was one of the
Orcs in Cirith Ungol from Barad-dûr. He was later killed fighting Morgul
Orcs over Frodo's Mithril-shirt.

name: Lagduf
text:
LAGDUF was an Orc of the Tower of Cirith Ungol. Biography Lagduf was
under the command of Shagrat; he and Muzgash were killed by Gorbag's
Orcs in the battle over Frodo's mithril-shirt.

name: Angelimir
text:
ANGELIMIR was the twentieth Prince of Dol Amroth.


Biography

Angelimir was the son of Aglahad. Little to nothing is known of his life
or reign. He married and had a son named Adrahil who succeeded him.

name: Iminyë
text:
IMINYË was an Elf of Cuiviénen.


Biography

Iminyë was awoken by the Elf who became her husband. She became the wife
of Imin, the first of the Elves to awaken in Cuivienen. Not much is
known about her life afterwards.

name: Rog
text:
ROG was an Elf of Gondolin during the First Age. Biography Rog was the
Lord of the House of the Hammer of Wrath in Gondolin. He was the
strongest of the Elves there. During the time of the Fall of Gondolin,
in which he died.
titles: Lord of the House of the Hammer of Wrath

name: Beldis
text:
BELDIS was an Edain woman of the House of Bëor.


Biography

Beldis was the daughter of Bregil. She married Handir of the House of
Haleth and a lord of that house. The couple had a son named Brandir,
who was born lame, for he had a club foot.

name: Dagnir
text:
DAGNIR (d. FA 460) was an Adan of the First House, one of the last
twelve survivors of Barahir's outlaw band in Dorthonion. He was killed
along with the others at Tarn Aeluin by a force sent by Sauron after
being betrayed by Gorlim the Unhappy.

name: Hild
text:
HILD was a noble woman who lived in Rohan.

She was the daughter of King Gram, the eighth King of Rohan and the
sister of Helm Hammerhand, the ninth King of Rohan. She was the mother
of Fréaláf, who became the first King of Rohan in the second line.

name: Orcobal
text:
ORCOBAL was an Orc chieftain of Angband during the First Age. Biography
Orcobal was only mentioned in Tolkien's first version of the The Fall of
Gondolin. He was killed in the onslaught by Ecthelion of the Fountain,
before one of the Gates of Gondolin.

name: Zamîn
text:
ZAMÎN was an old woman of Númenór who served Erendis, the wife of
Tar-Aldarion. She lived in the countryside of Emerië in an isolated
White House that belonged to Erendis. She befriended Ancalimë in her
childhood. Etymology _Zamîn_ seems to be an Adûnaic word.

name: Aglahad
text:
AGLAHAD was the nineteenth Prince of Dol Amroth.


Biography

In Aglahad's time, Gondor had to abandon Ithilien due to repeated
attacks by Uruks from Mordor and the refuge of Henneth Annûn was built.
Aglahad's son Angelimir became the twentieth Prince of Dol Amroth.

name: Penlod
text:
PENLOD was an Elf of Gondolin during the First Age. Biography Penlod was
the Lord of both the Gondolin houses Snow and Pillar. He died at the
Fall of Gondolin. He is not mentioned in the corresponding Silmarillion
chapter; rather, he appears only in The Book of Lost Tales 2.
titles: Lord of House of the Tower of Snow, Lord of House of the Pillar

name: Arciryas
text:
ARCIRYAS was a noble Man of Gondor.


Biography

Arciryas was the son of King Telumehtar Umbardacil and the younger
brother of King Narmacil II. Nothing is known of Arciryas life save that
he married an unnamed woman and their son was Calimmacil, who was an
ancestor of Eärnil II.

name: Ornendil
text:
ORNENDIL was the elder son of King Eldacar of Gondor.


Biography

In the siege of Osgiliath during the Kin-strife. Omendil's father was
driven out by Castamir the Usurper. Unfortunately, Ornendil did not
escape with his father and was put to death by Castamir upon the fall of
Osgiliath.

name: Malantur
text:
MALANTUR was a Númenorean noble, the son of Caliondo, son of Eärendur.
He lived during the late first millennium of the Second Age.

Malantur, it is said, was to be the heir to his cousin the king
Tar-Aldarion, but when laws were altered, the King's daughter Ancalimë
became heir instead.

name: Baranor
text:
BARANOR was a man of the House of Bëor.


Biography

Baranor was the brother of Boron and son of Baran; and therefore,
grandson of Bëor. He had one son called Bereg who led a group of
restless Men out of Estolad and southwards out of the Beleriand.

de:Baranor nl:Baranor pl:Baranor ru:Баранор

name: Nielíqui
text:
NIELÍQUI was a Valar and the daughter of Oromë and Vána in the earlier
forms of the legendarium. Biography Little is known about Nielíqui save
that she was small and a maiden that often danced in her father's woods.
The Vala Òmar was known to sing in gardens of Oromë nearby while she was
dancing.

name: Caliondo
text:
CALIONDO was the son of Eärendur, the second son of Tar-Amandil, the
third King of Númenor.


Biography

Caliondo was born to Eärendur and his unnamed wife in a unknown place in
Númenor. Caliondo had one child, a son named Malantur, the King's
presumptive heir. Nothing else is known about his life.

name: Gostir
text:
GOSTIR was the name of one of the Dragons of Morgoth about whom almost
nothing is known. Biography Gostir was a dragon only known by name.
Etymology _GOSTIR_ means “terrible sight” in Sindarin, from _gos_
(“horrible”) and _thîr_ (“opinion, expression, face”). The earlier form
of the name was GORSTHIR.

name: Frumgar
text:
FRUMGAR was the fourth Lord of the Éothéod and the ancestor of Eorl the
Young.


Biography

Frumgar led his people away from the Vales of Anduin in a migration to
the land between the rivers Langwell and Greylin after the overthrown of
Angmar, to escape the ever increasing dangers of their former home.

name: Ebor
text:
EBOR was the son of Meleth and Agathora, and brother to Manthor, his
lord, and Hunthor.


History

Ebor appears in the account of the wanderings of Hurin, after the death
of Turin Turambar. He was a captain of men of Brethil, to whom Asgon and
his men were brought after being captured by march-wardens.

name: Borlad
text:
BORLAD was the son of Bór, possibly the eldest of his three sons.


Biography

Borlad fought with the Union of Maedhros at the Nirnaeth Arnoediad and
like his father and two brothers remained loyal to the Sons of Fëanor,
unlike those of Ulfang who betrayed them. He was slain fighting against
the traitors.

name: Nan
text:
NAN was a Giant, mentioned only in ''The Book of Lost Tales 2, ''for
whom the Nauglafring (the early name of the Necklace of the Dwarves) was
made. He and another Giant Gilim are not told of in _The Silmarillion_.

Nan is told in _The Tale of Tinúviel_ to have owned a particularly long
sword, named Glend.

name: Arthad
text:
ARTHAD was an Edain Man of the House of Bëor.


Biography

Arthad was a Men of Dorthonion before the Dagor Bragollach. Afterwards,
he was one of Barahir's Outlaws that lived in Dorthonion deifying
Morgoth's forces. He was killed along with the other outlaws at Tarn
Aeluin as a result of Gorlim's betrayal.

name: Fosco Baggins
text:
FOSCO BAGGINS was a Hobbit of the Shire and the grandfather of Frodo
Baggins.


Biography

Fosco was the son of Largo Baggins and Tanta (Hornblower) Baggins. Fosco
married Ruby Bolger and they had three children Dora, Drogo and Dudo.
Their son Drogo was the father of Frodo Baggins. Fosco died in TA 2960
(SR 1360).

name: Artamir
text:
ARTAMIR was the eldest son of King Ondoher of Gondor. He, his father,
and his younger brother were killed in battle with the Wainriders.


Etymology

The name _ARTAMIR_ comes from Quenya and means “noble jewel”. It is made
from the words _arta_, meaning “exalted” or “noble”, and _mírë_, meaning
“treasure” or “jewel”.

name: Adrahil II
text:
ADRAHIL II was the twenty-first Prince of Dol Amroth.


Biography

Adrahil was the only son of Angelimir. He succeeded his father on TA
2977. He was the father of Ivriniel, Finduilas, and the famed Prince
Imrahil. He reigned for thirty-three years, during the stewardship of
Ecthelion II and the start of Denethor II's.

name: Atanatar I
text:
ATANATAR I was the tenth King of Gondor.


Biography

Atanatar was the son of Turambar and succeeded his father to the throne
of Gondor in TA 667. His reign was uneventful and presumably peaceful.
He died in TA 748 and was succeeded by his son Siriondil.


Etymology

Atanatar was a Quenya word that meant 'man-father'.

name: Borthand
text:
BORTHAND was the Easterling Man, son of Bór, possibly the youngest of
his three sons.


Biography

Borthand fought with the Union of Maedhros at the Nirnaeth Arnoediad and
like his father and two brothers remained loyal to the Sons of Fëanor,
unlike those of Ulfang who betrayed them. He was slain fighting against
the traitors.

name: Arantar
text:
ARANTAR was the fifth King of Arnor.


Biography

Arantar ascended the throne of Arnor in TA 339 on the death of his
father Eldacar; he was the great-grandson of Isildur. The ninety-six
years of his reign was without any major events, and he died in TA 435
at the age of two-hundred and fifty. He was succeeded by his son
Tarcil.

name: Ardamir (son of Axantur)
text:
ARDAMIR was a Man of Númenór.


Biography

Ardamir was the second child and son of the nobleman Axantur. He had two
other siblings: Lindissë and Cemendur. Little of his life is known but
like his father, his descendants would enter into the ruling line
through Hallacar, his great-nephew who married Tar-Ancalimë, the first
Ruling Queen of Númenor.

name: Herumor (Fourth Age)
text:
HERUMOR was a leader of a secret cult growing in Gondor during the
Fourth Age. He was an adept of Darkness. Biography Around FO 220,
Herumor led a secret cult which worshiped Melkor, Sauron and Saruman. He
fought against Eldarion and the Reunited Kingdom. Etymology The name
HERUMOR translates into “Dark Lord” from _heru_ (“lord”) and _mor_
(“dark”).

name: Aranwë
text:
ARANWË was an Elf of Gondolin and the father of Voronwë. His son
stated that he was from the House of Fingolfin, suggesting that Aranwë
might have been a noble elf in Gondolin.


Etymology

The Quenyan name ARANWË means “Kingly” or “Noble” from _ara_ (“noble”)
and _aran_ (“king”). The suffix _-wë_ occur in many names, though not
exclusively masculine.
birth: YT ? during the Noontide of Valinor

name: Gilmith
text:
GILMITH was the daughter of Imrazôr and Mithrellas and the sister of
Galador, the first Prince of Dol Amroth. Biography Gilmith probably
lived with her family in Edhellond or Dol Amroth. Virtually nothing else
is known about her so it is not clear what she did during her life,
whether she married anyone, or what eventually became of her in later
days.

name: Borin
text:
BORIN was a Dwarf of Durin's Folk, the second son of King Náin II and
brother of Dáin I.


Biography

After his brother and younger nephew Frór were slain, Borin departed
from the Grey Mountains with his younger nephew Thrór to the Lonely
Mountain and lived there until his death. He was an ancestor of both
Balin and Gimli of the Fellowship of the Ring.

name: Gamil Zirak
text:
GAMIL ZIRAK was a Dwarvish smith, who was the master of Telchar of
Nogrod in the early First Age. Gamil was a great craftsman, whose work
was found in the treasuries of Elu Thingol. He was commonly referred to
as “the old”; ZIRAK THE OLD.


Etymology

“Zirak” is a Khazad word, appearing in Zirakzigil also. But the meaning
of Gamil's name isn't specified.

name: Baran
text:
BARAN was an Edain Man of the House of Bëor, who lived during the First
Age.


Biography

Baran was the eldest son of Bëor the Old. He had a younger brother named
Belen. Like the folk of Bëor, he lived in Estolad. Baran took the
leadership of the House of Bëor when his father departed to
Nargothrond. He dwelt in Estolad and had two sons, Boron and Baranor.

name: Bregolas
text:
BREGOLAS was one of the Edain of the House of Bëor. He was also the
third Lord of Ladros.


Biography

Bregolas was the brother of Barahir and Bregil, and the son of
Bregor. He became the third Lord of Ladros after the death of his
father. He was killed in the Dagor Bragollach defending Dorthonion with
Angrod and Aegnor. His sons were Baragund and Belegund.
titles: Chieftain of the House of Bëor, Lord of Ladros

name: Boron
text:
BORON was an Edain of the House of Bëor.


Biography

Boron was eldest son of Baran, grandson of Bëor. He had a younger
brother named Baranor. He was the third chieftain of the House of Bëor.
He was married to an unnamed woman. They had at least two children
Andreth and Boromir, who later became the first Lord of Ladros.


He lived in Dorthonion; probably in Ladros.
titles: Chieftain of the House of Bëor

name: Minastan
text:
MINASTAN was a man of Gondor, born sometime after TA 1516, who was the
second son of Minardil and father of Tarondor. His elder brother
Telemnar was King of Gondor for only two years until he died in the
Great Plague of 1636. Minastan might have died too in that Plague, or
else he died earlier. 

Minastan's son succeeded Telemnar on the throne, beginning a new
line.

name: Bereg
text:
BEREG was a man of the House of Bëor.


Biography

Bereg, the grandson of Baran through Baranor, Baran's youngest son, was
dissatisfied with Estolad, and so he in about FA 365 led a thousand men
of the House of Bëor away southwards out of the Beleriand, disappearing
from the histories. It is possible some of his descendants were the
ancestors of the later Men of Eriador.

name: Haldar
text:
HALDAR (born FA 341 - died FA 375) was the son of Haldad, leader of the
Haladin (House of Haleth), twin brother to Haleth and the father of
Haldan.  He came to the Beleriand with his family and his people in
the year 420.

He died in the Battle of the Gelion, attempting to retrieve the body of
his father, who was slain while trying to lead a sortie against a siege
of orcs.
death: F.A. 375, Battle of the Gelion-Ascar Stockade

name: Madoc Brandybuck
text:
MADOC “PROUDNECK” BRANDYBUCK was a Hobbit of Buckland and the third
Master of Buckland.


Biography

Madoc was born on SR 1175 (TA 2775) and was the son of Gormadoc
Brandybuck and Malva Headstrong. He married Hanna Goldworthy of the
Shire and had one son with her, Marmadoc “Masterful”. Madoc was the
third Master of Buckland from SR 1236 until his death on SR 1277 at age
102.

name: Lorgan
text:
LORGAN was the chief of the Easterlings in Hithlum after the Nirnaeth
Arnoediad, with claims on Dor-Lómin as well.


Biography

Lorgan was cruel slavemaster holding many Men and perhaps Elves in
thralldom. Forcibly taking him away from his Elf protectors, he enslaved
Tuor for three years until he managed to escape out of the north.
Afterwards, Lorgan put a price on his head.

name: Amrothos
text:
AMROTHOS was the third son and the second child of Imrahil, the
twenty-second Prince of Dol Amroth.


Biography

Amrothos was born in TA 2994. He had three siblings: two older brothers,
Elphir, Erchirion, and a younger sister, Lothíriel, who would later
marry Éomer and become the Queen of Rohan.

He was a grown man during the War of the Ring, but his service in it is
unknown.

name: Adrahil I
text:
ADRAHIL I was a Dúnedain and Man of Gondor and the Prince of
Dor-en-Ernil.


Biography

Adrahil was born sometime before TA 1944. He was of traceable Númenórean
lineage. He served King Ondoher of Gondor as a general of the forces of
Gondor during the wars with the Wainriders in TA 1944.  Whether he
was an ancestor of Adrahil II, the father of Imrahil of Dol Amroth, is
unknown.

name: Saradoc Brandybuck
text:
Saradoc Brandybuck, nicknamed “Scattergold,” was married to Esmeralda
Took and was the father of Meriadoc. He lived from 1340-1432 Shire
Reckoning and attended Bilbo Baggins's birthday party in 1401 Shire
Reckoning. He was the son of Old Rory Brandybuck, who also attended the
party and was the only one to realize that Bilbo was truly leaving.
Saradoc was Frodo Baggins's cousin.

name: Ulrad
text:
ULRAD was one of the men in the outlaw band led by Turin. He was a
friend of the man that Turin killed to gain entry to the band. He
contested Turin's right to be accepted into the outlaws. He is partly
held responsible by Mim the petty dwarf for not being able to speak to
his so before he died because Ulrad was one of the men that bound him.
Ulrad's fate is not revealed after this.

name: Amlach
text:
AMLACH SON OF IMLACH was one of the Edain, and an ancestor of Hador
Lorindol born in FA 337. History Amlach was a grandson of Marach, the
leader of the third host of men to enter Beleriand, and an ancestor of
Hador Lorindol. Originally, he did not trust the elves, and was the
leader of disssention among the Men of Estolad. Later on, he repented
and entered into the service of Maedhros.

name: Náin I
text:
Náin I was the son of Durin VI, and succeeded his father as King of
Khazad-dûm.


Biography

When his father was slain by the Balrog, Náin I attempted to destroy it,
but was himself killed the following year. The remainder of Durin's Folk
fled Khazad-dûm, and renamed it Moria. He was succeeded on the throne of
Durin's Folk by his son Thráin I who fled to the Grey Mountains and the
Lonely Mountain.
titles: King of Durin's Folk, King of Khazad-dûm

name: Otho Sackville-Baggins
text:
OTHO SACKVILLE-BAGGINS was a Hobbit of the Shire.


Biography

Otho adopted the name of both his parents, Longo Baggins and Camellia
Sackville, effectively founding a new family. He was the head of the
family for many years and his son Lotho had ambitions to succeed Bilbo
(and later Frodo) as head of the Baggins family; had that happened
before he died, Lotho would have called himself
'Baggins-Sackville-Baggins'.

name: Ailinel
text:
AILINEL was the second daughter of Tar-Meneldur and Almarian and the
mother of Soronto.


Biography

Ailinel was born between the years SA 700 and SA 750. Her brother
Aldarion became Tar-Aldarion, and her younger sister was Almiel. She
married a man named Orchaldor, by whom she had a son, Soronto.


Etymology

The name _Ailinel_ might be related to the Quenya term _aelin_ (“lake,
pool”) and the feminine suffix _-el_.

name: Enthor
text:
'''Enthor '''was a Man of Brethil, married to Hiril, and the father of
Meleth.

Hunthor, a friend of Túrin Turambar , and Manthor, a friend Húrin
Thalion after Túrin's death, were Enthor's grandsons.


Earlier versions of the legendarium

In an earlier version of _The Wanderings of Húrin_, Enthor was a younger
brother of Hunthor and Manthor. Later, he became the forerunning
character to Ebor, a henchman of Manthor's.

name: Buffo Boffin
text:
BUFFO BOFFIN was a Hobbit of the Shire.


Biography

Although not officially announced, it is believed Buffo may have lived
around 250 years before the War of the Ring. Buffo was the first
recorded Boffin according to the Boffin family tree. He lived in The
Yale which would become the traditional home of the family. He was the
husband of Ivy Goodenough. With her he had four children - Bosco, Basso,
Briffo and Berylla.

name: Nurwë
text:
NURWË was an elf from Cuiviénen who refused the summons of the Valar.


Biography

When the three ambassadors of the Elves, Ingwë, Finwë, and Elwë returned
from Aman, they invited the other Elves to travel there. However, Nurwë
and Morwë refused, thus leading the Avari left behind.


Etymology

The Quenyan term _nur_ or _nura_ means (“to separate”) and _-wë_ may
have come from _-wego_ which is frequent in masculine names.
birth: during the Years of the Trees

name: Snaga (Grishnakh's band)
text:
SNAGA was an Orc in Grishnakh's band. Biography Snaga was a scout in the
band of Mordor Orcs sent by Sauron that meet Uglúk's group and their
captives Meriadoc Brandybuck and Peregrin Took in _The Two Towers_. When
Uglúk believed that the Rohirrim had been made aware of them, he was
blamed for it. The Uruk-hai chieftain threatened that he would cut off
his ears. Snaga was killed along with the rest by Éomer's band of
riders.

name: Lungorthin
text:
LUNGORTHIN was a Balrog mentioned in earlier versions of _The
Silmarillion_. Biography Like Gothmog, he bore the title of “Lord of
Balrogs”. He was the captain of security in Angband and, like his
superior officer, Gothmog, was fiercely loyal to his lord, Morgoth. It
is unknown if he was an earlier version of Gothmog, but he might have
been a different Balrog altogether. de:Lungorthin es:Lungorthin
it:Lungorthin ru:Лунгортин
titles: Lord of Balrogs, Captain of Angband

name: Beechbone
text:
BEECHBONE was one of the younger Ents who lived in the Fangorn Forest.
Biography Not much is known about the life of Beechbone, apart from that
he took part in Battle of Isengard with the other Ents on March 3, 3019.
In the book _The Two Towers_, he was caught on fire by the gas let out
by the Uruk-hai and apparently burned to death. However, this only
encouraged the other Ents to double their efforts in destroying
Isengard.

name: Axantur
text:
AXANTUR was a nobleman of Númenor.


Biography

Axantur was the son of Nolondil and the cousin of King Tar-Elendil. He
had two other siblings: Yávien and Oromendil. He married an unnamed
woman and had three children named Lindissë, Ardamir, and Cemendur.
Little of Axantur's life is known but his descendants would enter into
the ruling line and his great-grandson Hallacar would marry
Tar-Ancalimë, the first Ruling Queen of Númenor.

name: Melilot Brandybuck
text:
MELILOT BRANDYBUCK was a Hobbit of the Shire.


Biography

Melilot was born in SR 1385 (TA 2985) and was the youngest child of
Marmadas Brandybuck. Melilot's siblings were called Merimas and
Mentha. At Bilbo's 111th birthday party on September 22, 3001,
Melilot Brandybuck and Everard Took began to dance the Springle-ring on
a table when they mistakenly thought Bilbo's speech was over. She was a
third cousin of Meriadoc Brandybuck.

name: Meneldor
text:
MENELDOR was a Great Eagle who dwelt at the Eagles Eyrie, at the north
half of the Misty Mountains. Biography He was a friend and follower of
Gwaihir and probably dwelt with him on their eyrie in the Misty
Mountains. He along with Gwaihir and Landroval was one of the Eagles who
rescued Frodo and Sam from the slopes of Mount Doom (Orodruin), after
the destruction of the Ring. Etymology The first element of his name,
_menel_, means “heaven”.

name: Ufthak
text:
UFTHAK was a Mordor Orc serving in the Tower of Cirith Ungol. Biography
At some undermined time while with a band of fellow Orcs including
Shagrat, Ufthak got lost in the tunnels and was caught by Shelob,
poisoned and hung up in a corner. When the others found him, he was
still alive and awake but did nothing to help him, out of fear of what
would happen if they interfered with her work. Etymology Ufthak in the
Black Speech meant “Ugly Faced”.

name: Aranuir
text:
ARANUIR was the third Chieftain of the Dúnedain.


Biography

Aranuir was the son of Arahael and great-grandson of Arvedui Last-King.
He was the direct ancestor of Aragorn Elessar through thirteen
generations. Aranuir died in TA 2247. Little is recorded on Aranuir's
life or reign but it could be assumed that it was relatively uneventful.


Etymology

His name possibly means “Eternal King”, from the Sindarin _aran_
(“king”) and _uir_ (“eternity”).

name: Herumor
text:
HERUMOR was a Black Númenórean lord. Biography Like all Black
Númenóreans, Herumor fell under the influence of the Dark Lord Sauron
during the late Second Age while he was on the island of Númenór. He
sailed east with Fuinur and with him settled with Haradrim in the lands
of Harad, and the two became lords among the Haradrim. His ultimate fate
is unknown. Etymology HERUMOR means “Lord of the dark” in Sindarin, from
_heru_ (“lord”) and _mor_ (“dark”).

name: Orleg
text:
ORLEG was an Edain of the First Age. Biography Orleg was one of the
bandits that Túrin joined. He ventured out with Túrin, now the captain,
but were spotted by Orcs who thought them spies of Nargothrond and were
forced to flee westward. The Orcs pursued them to the death forcing them
out of the forest and into the open and were then espied, and as the two
were going to cross a road Orleg was slain by many arrows. Túrin was
however able to save his Elven-mail.

name: Borlach
text:
BORLACH was an Easterling of the First Age.


Biography

Borlach was an Easterling Man from Lothlann, alive during the First Age.
He was the son of Bór and fought with the Union of Maedhros at the
Nirnaeth Arnoediad (Battle of Unnumbered Tears). Like his father and his
two brothers Borlad and Borthand, Borlach remained loyal to the Sons of
Fëanor, unlike the Easterlings who followed Ulfang, who betrayed them.
He was slain in the battle, while fighting against the traitors.

name: Marcho
text:
MARCHO was a Fallohide-hobbit adventurer and one of the founders of the
Shire.


Biography

Originally living in Bree, he and his brother Blanco and a large
following of Hobbits, having obtained permission from the King of
Arthedain seated at Fornost at the time to do so, decided to journey
westward in search of new lands to settle. By TA 1601, he and his
followers reached a rich and fertile land, between the Brandywine River
and the Far Downs, where they founded The Shire.

name: Esmeralda Brandybuck
text:
ESMERALDA BRANDYBUCK was a Hobbit of the Shire.


Biography

Esmeralda was born to Adalgrim Took and his unnamed wife. She was the
youngest of their five children. She was a descendant of Gerontius Took,
and younger sister to Thain Paladin Took II. She married Saradoc
Brandybuck, the Master of Buckland making her the Mistress of Buckland
and of Brandy Hall. Being a Took and marrying into the Brandybuck
family, she was both Peregrin Took's aunt and Merry Brandybuck's
mother.

name: Mentha Brandybuck
text:
MENTHA BRANDYBUCK was a young and beautiful Hobbit who lived in the
country of Buckland, which bordered east from the Shire during the Third
Age.


Biography

Born in TA 2983 (SR 1383) in Buckland, Mentha was the second child of
Marmadas Brandybuck and granddaughter of Gorbulas Brandybuck. Her older
brother was Merimas and her younger sister was Melilot. In TA 3001,
Mentha was already 18 years old when se and her entire Brandybuck clan
attended Bilbo's Farewell Birthday Party.

name: Baragund
text:
BARAGUND was an Edain of the House of Bëor.


Biography

Baragund was the son of Bregolas and a direct descendant of Bëor the
Old. He had one daughter, Morwen and he was the grandfather of Túrin
Turambar. He and his family lived peacefully in Dorthonion before the
Dagor Bragollach. He survived the battle and lived as an outlaw with his
uncle Barahir and some companions for nearly five years. They were
eventually betrayed to Sauron by the unhappy Gorlim and killed at Tarn
Aeluin.

name: Balbo Baggins
text:
BALBO BAGGINS was a Hobbit of the Shire and the first recorded member of
the Baggins family.


Biography

Balbo Baggins married Berylla Boffin and had five children: Mungo,
Pansy, Ponto, Largo, and Lily. Balbo was the first recorded Baggins ever
known in the Shire, and the ancestor of the Baggins family of
Hobbiton.


Note

On Balbo's dates: In the published Baggins genealogy only Balbo's
birthdate is shown, but by looking at his children it is possible to
estimate his deathdate.

name: Mat Heathertoes
text:
MAT HEATHERTOES was a Man of Bree who died in the year 3019 of the Third
Age, along with two other Men and two Hobbits. Biography There had been
much change brought about by the 'Scouring of the Shire' at the end of
the War of the Ring, and many refugees had fled to Bree. This caused
much unrest amongst the locals and in 3019 Bill Ferny, accompanied by
several others, got into a brawl with a group of natives, including
Heathertoes. Mat Heathertoes was amongst the several casualties.

name: Minto Burrows
text:
MINTO BURROWS was a Hobbit of the Shire.


Biography

Minto was born in TA 2996 (SR 1396) and was a descendant of the Masters
of Buckland who could trace his ancestry back to Gorbadoc Brandybuck. He
was the youngest of the four children of Milo Burrows and Peony Baggins.
Little is known of his life other than that while his parents and his
siblings Mosco, Moro and Myrtle all attended Bilbo's famous Birthday
Party, Minto did not (possibly because he was only five years old at the
time).

name: Fuinur
text:
FUINUR was a Black Númenórean lord. Biography Like all Black
Númenóreans, Fuinur fell under the influence of the Dark Lord Sauron
during the late Second Age while he was on the island of Númenór. He
sailed east with Herumor to the lands of Harad, and the two became lords
among the Haradrim. Etymology The name FUINUR comes from the word
_fuinë_, meaning “deep shadow”. There appears to be no definitive origin
of the word _fuinë_, though it may have been borrowed into Quenya from
Telerin.

name: Atanalcar
text:
ATANALCAR was the youngest child and third son of Elros Tar-Minyatur,
Half-elven and first King of Númenor.


Biography

Atanalcar was born after SA 61 and was the younger brother of Manwendil,
Tindómiel, and the short reigning king Vardamir Nólimon. Nothing else is
known of his life only that he was possibly married and had children.


Etymology

ATANALCAR is a Quenyan name meaning “Man glory”. It is made from the
words _atan_ (“man”) and _alcar_ (“glory, radiance, brilliance or
splendour”).

name: Blanco
text:
BLANCO was a Fallohide Hobbit adventurer and one of the two recognized
founders of the Shire.


Biography

Originally living in Bree, Blanco and his brother Marcho and a large
following of Hobbits having obtained permission from the King of
Arthedain, Argeleb II, seated at Fornost at the time to do so, decided
to journey westward in search of new lands to settle. By TA 1601, he and
his followers reached a rich and fertile land between the Brandywine
River and the Far Downs where they founded The Shire.
birth: YT ? during the Noontide of Valinor

name: Alphros
text:
ALPHROS was the twenty-fourth Prince of Dol Amroth.


Biography

Alphros was the son of Elphir and was a child during the War of the
Ring. When Aragorn II Elessar became King of the Reunited Kingdom,
Alphros succeeded his father as Prince of Dol Amroth and served under
Aragorn, until Alphros's death in FO 95.


Etymology

The name ALPHROS means “Swan-foam”, from the Sindarin _alph_ (“swan”)
and _ros_ (“foam”).


Other versions of the legendarium

In earlier writings, his death date was placed in FO 98.

name: Calmacil
text:
CALMACIL (TA 1058 - TA 1304, r. TA 1294 - TA 1304) was the eighteenth
King of Gondor and the brother of Narmacil I, whom he succeeded as King
in TA 1294.

His reign lasted for ten years, in which his son Minalcar (known later
as Rómendacil II) continued his function as Regent, a function he had
held during Narmacil's reign. It therefore would seem he never held
(nor, perhaps, desired) any actual power.

In TA 1304 he died and was succeeded by Minalcar.

name: Estella Bolger
text:
ESTELLA (BOLGER) BRANDYBUCK was a Hobbit of the Shire.


History

Estella was born in TA 2985 (SR 1385) was the sister of Fredegar “Fatty”
Bolger, the companion that Frodo, Merry, Pippin, and Sam left behind in
Crickhollow at the start of _The Fellowship of the Ring_. Estella was
the daughter of Odovacar Bolger and Rosamunda Took. She married Master
Meriadoc Brandybuck of Buckland, and had at least one son. Estella
probably died sometime before the year 63 of the Fourth Age when Merry
left the Shire to live in Gondor.

name: Arador
text:
ARADOR was the fourteenth Chieftain of the Dúnedain.


Biography

Arador descended in right line from Aranarth the son of Arvedui. While
still a young man by the account of the Dúnedain of the North, he was
captured by Hill-trolls in the Coldfells north of Rivendell, and
slain. He was succeeded by his son, who led the Dúnedain of the North
and the Rangers of the North as Arathorn II, and was in turn succeeded
by his own son Aragorn, the future King of Gondor and Arnor.


Etymology

Arador means 'royal lord' in Sindarin.

name: Inzilbêth
text:
INZILBÊTH was a noble Woman of Númenór and the wife of Ar-Gimilzôr, the
twenty-third King of Númenor.


Biography

Inzilbêth was the daughter of Lindórië, who was herself a descendant of
Tar-Elendil, the fourth King of Númenor, and also of Tar-Calmacil.
Inzilbêth was secretly one of The Faithful, and she passed on her ways
to their son, Tar-Palantir. Their second son, Gimilkhâd, opposed his
elder brother's policies and continued practicing the beliefs of the
King's Men in secret.


Etymology

Her name seems to be Adûnaic.

name: Aulendil (Vardamir's son)
text:
AULENDIL was the third child and the second son of the short-reigning
king, Vardamir Nólimon.


Biography

Aulendil was born in Númenor in an unknown location. He had three
siblings, the younger Nolondil and the older Vardilmë, and the oldest
Tar-Amandil who would later be crowned the third King of Númenor.
Nothing else is known about his life, only that he was married and had
children.


Etymology

AULENDIL was a Quenya word that meant “Devoted to Aulë”. It was also
the same name that Sauron gave himself in the Second Age.

name: Bucca of the Marish
text:
BUCCA OF THE MARISH was a Hobbit of the Shire and the first Thain of the
Shire. He originated from the Marish region of the Shire.


Biography

Being a well-respected hobbit, Bucca became Thain in place of the King
at Fornost in TA 1979 (SR 379). He founded the family of the
Oldbucks, who later became the Brandybucks, after settling in the later
Eastfarthing. Other aspects of Bucca's life are not known, as was his
eventual fate.


Etymology

The name BUCCA came from the Old English _bucc_ (“male deer”) or _bucca_
(“he-goat”).

name: Belegorn
text:
BELEGORN was the fourth Ruling Steward of Gondor.


Biography

Belegorn was born in TA 2074 and was the son of Herion. Following the
death of his father, Herion, in TA 2148 Belegorn became the fourth
Ruling Steward of Gondor, and the fourth steward to rule during the era
known as the Watchful Peace. Belegorn ruled Gondor until his death in
the year TA 2204 at the age of 130 years old. He was succeeded by his
son Húrin I.


Etymology

In Sindarin, the name BELEGORN means “Mighty tree”, from _beleg_
(“mighty”) and _orn_ (“tree”).

name: Aghan
text:
AGHAN was a dark-skinned man of the Drúedain tribes. He had a friend
called Barach, who lived on the borders of Forest of Brethil, two miles
away from the nearest village. Aghan took to watching their house when
orcs started raiding nearby.When his brother was ill, he made a statue
to watch the house. When a group of orcs stared burning Barach's house,
a mysterious Drug killed the orcs and put out the fires, but was burned
by the flames. Aghan suffered from blisters at the same time. The
mysterious Drug turned out to be the statue.

name: Ulwarth
text:
ULWARTH was an Easterling Man and the son of Ulfang.


Biography

Like his father, Ulwarth entered the Beleriand and pledged his service
to the Sons of Fëanor. They served under Caranthir but their only true
loyalty was to Morgoth, and their purpose was to betray him at the right
time. During a critical time during the Nirnaeth Arnoediad, he turned
on Caranthir attacking at them from the rear. When Bór and the other
faithful Easterlings saw what they were doing, Bór and his men slew him
and his father and brothers Ulfast and Uldor.

name: Berylla Boffin
text:
BERYLLA (BOFFIN) BAGGINS was a Hobbit of the Shire and the wife of Balbo
Baggins, the first recorded member of the Baggins family.


Biography

Berylla was born in TA 2772 (SR 1172) to Buffo Boffin and Ivy
Goodenough. She married Balbo Baggins and was the mother of Mungo,
Pansy, Ponto, Largo, and Lily Goodbody. She died in TA 2871 (SR
1271).


Behind the Scenes

Her years of birth and death are not given in _The Lord of the Rings_,
but a birth-year of 2772 for her appears on Boffin family tree 'BF4' in
_The Peoples of Middle-earth_.

name: Haldad
text:
HALDAD was a leader of the Haladin (House of Haleth) in Thargelion.

He became their leader when a swarm of orcs assaulted his people. He
created a defensive stockade between the two rivers Gelion and Ascar and
was besieged by orcs. They exhausted their food supply, and Haldad led a
sortie against the orcs, only to be slain. His son, Haldar, was also
slain while trying to retrieve his body. His daughter, Haleth, led the
Haladin through another week of starvation until Caranthir and his army
rescued them.

name: Galador
text:
GALADOR was a Half-elven Dúnedain Man of Gondor and the First Prince of
Dol Amroth. Biography Galador's lineage is partially couched in legend
but he was the Half-elven son of the Númenórean Imrazôr and the Elf
Maiden Mithrellas. He had a sister named Gilmith. The accounts of his
early life are not known but he probably lived in Edhellond with his
father and other Men and Elves. After the loss of Amroth in the sea and
probably his father as well, he assumed the leadership of the peoples of
Edhellond and became the first Prince of Dol Amroth.

name: Bór
text:
BÓR was a leader of Easterling Men of the First Age.


Biography

Bór came into Lothlann, Beleriand, in the year FA 463. His sons were
Borlach, Borlad, and Borthand. Bór was welcomed by Maedhros, who gave
him and his followers land north of the March of Maedhros, and south of
it. Bór and his sons swore allegiance to Maedhros, and remained
faithful, though he was told by Morgoth to betray the banner of
Caranthir. He and his sons remained faithful to the Noldor unlike
Ulfang's followers. All of them were wiped out during the Nirnaeth
Arnoediad.

name: Imin
text:
IMIN was an Elf of Cuiviénen. He was best known as the first Elf to
awake.


Biography

Imin was awoken in Cuiviénen by the divine will of Eru Ilúvatar in the
Years of the Trees. Along with Tata and Enel, he awoke twelve other
Elves which took him as their lord. From there he founded the Minyar
which later was called the Vanyar. It is not known why he wasn't chosen
as ambassador to Valinor nor why he didn't become his clan's first king.
His fate is unknown but presumably he lived. His wife was Iminyë.


Etymology

He was called IMIN, THE FIRST.

name: Ar-Zimrathôn
text:
AR-ZIMRATHÔN was the twenty-first King of Númenor.


Biography

Like his father Ar-Adûnakhôr, Ar-Zimrathôn opposed the Valar, and he
took his name in the Adûnaic tongue rather than in the traditional
Quenya. But Númenórean scholars recorded his Quenya name Tar-Hostamir so
as to not offend the Valar. His name in both languages means “Jewel
Gatherer”, perhaps implying a greedy nature.

Ar-Zimrathôn died in SA 3033, living to the age of two-hundred and
thirty-five and ruled Númenor for seventy-one years, and was succeeded
by his son, Ar-Sakalthôr.

name: Ibûn
text:
IBÛN was a Petty-dwarf, was the son of Mîm and brother of Khîm.


Biography

He was captured with his father and brother by Túrin's outlaw band.
During the Sack of Amon Rûdh, he was missing in action. He might have
been killed by an orc or might of died of an accident like his brother.
But after the destruction of Amon Rudh, he was never seen again.


Behind the scenes

In _The Children of Hurin_ and _Unfinished Tales_, Ibûn is last
mentioned being held hostage by the Orcs that Mîm had aligned himself
with, but he is never mentioned again after that.

name: Primula Brandybuck
text:
PRIMULA BAGGINS was a Hobbit of the Shire, the mother of Frodo Baggins,
who was one of the many bearers of the Ring, and the cousin of Bilbo
Baggins.


Biography

Primula was a daughter of Gorbadoc Brandybuck, Master of Buckland, and
Mirabella Took, the youngest daughter of the Old Took. She married Drogo
Baggins, and had one child, Frodo. In TA 2980 (SR 1380), she and her
husband were drowned in the Brandywine River, leaving Frodo an orphaned
child. She was sixty years old.


Etymology

Primula was a species of the Primrose family of flowering plants.

name: Belemir
text:
BELEMIR was an Edain of the House of Bëor during the First Age.


Biography

Belemir was the son of Beldir who was a great-grandson of Bëor himself
through his father Belen, the youngest son of Bëor. He married Adanel of
the House of Marach who was the grand-daughter of Marach himself. It was
told that Belemir had five children with Adanel, the fifth child being a
son called Beren who became the grandfather of the renowned Beren _the
One-handed_ by his famed daughter Emeldir _the Man-hearted_. Hence,
Belemir was the great-grandfather of Beren the renowned.

name: Galion
text:
GALION was a Nandorin Wood-elf of the Woodland Realm in Northern
Mirkwood.


Biography

Galion was the King's butler and was probably one of his many servants.
He was also charged with shipping out the empty barrels into the
underground river down the Long Lake and finally back to Lake-town. He
was very fond of his wine. It is not known when or where he was actually
born or if he lived in the realm when it was known as _Greenwood the
Great_. Drinking with the guard captain, he fell asleep allowing Bilbo
to steal the keys and release the Dwarves from prison.

name: Brodda
text:
BRODDA was an Easterling lord who ruled Dor-lómin for a while. He took
Aerin as his wife, and was later killed by Túrin Turambar. Biography
Brodda was a lord of the Easterlings. He usurped the lordship of
Dor-lómin after Húrin was captured, and Morwen had since left the area.
He married Aerin sometime after that. A little while before the coming
of 499, the First Age, Brodda was involved in a battle that took place
inside the hall of his own grandious home. He was ultimately murdered by
Túrin in his rage, even though Brodda was innocent and befriended Túrin.

name: Fladrif
text:
FLADRIF (SKINBARK) is an ent of the Fangorn Forest, and was one of the
first Ents in Middle-earth. By the end of the Third Age, only he,
Leaflock, and Treebeard remained of the original Ents. Skinbark lived on
the mountain slopes west of Isengard. Saruman's orcs ravaged this area,
cutting down trees and killing Ents. Skinbark was wounded by the orcs
and he retreated far up the mountain slopes to live among the birches
that he favored. He refused to come down. He took part in the Battle of
Isengard, and is seen crushing dozens of orcs under a rolling boulder.

name: Îbal
text:
ÎBAL was a Númenórean child. Biography Îbal was the son of Ulbar, a Man
who once served with the great Númenórean captain and future King of
Númenor Aldarion was boy living in the pleasant region of Emerië in the
part of the Second Age. As a boy, he knew Ancalimë when she was just a
girl and living in the White House. He greatly wished to be a mariner
like his father had become and to sail the great seas of the world.
Whether he fulfilled that dream is unknown. He lived on a farm close to
the White House and would frequently run errands between the two places.

name: Almiel
text:
ALMIEL was the third child of Tar-Meneldur and younger sister of Ailinel
and Tar-Aldarion.


Biography

Almiel was born between SA 700 and SA 750 in the Númenórean province of
Forostar. She had two other siblings: Aldarion, who would later become
the sixth King of Númenor, ruling as Tar-Aldarion and an older sister
named Ailinel. Nothing else is known about her expect that she was
probably close to her noble family and their in-laws.


Etymology

The name ALMIEL might be related to the Quenya term _alma_ (“good
fortune”) and _-iel_ a feminine patronymic suffix.

name: Gorbag
text:
GORBAG was an Orc captain of Cirith Ungol during the Third Age,
originally from Minas Morgul.


Biography



After Shelob paralyzed Frodo Baggins, two Orc patrols led by Gorbag and
Shagrat came across his cocooned body, taking him back to Cirith Ungol
where they planned to torture him. While sifting through Frodo's
belongings, a dispute began between the two captains over Frodo's
Mithril vest, which escalated into a vicious fight all over the fortress
between the Morgul and Cirith Ungol Orcs. Gorbag survived much of the
fight but was eventually killed by Shagrat.

name: Aldamir
text:
ALDAMIR was the twenty-third King of Gondor (Castamir being counted the
twenty-second).


Biography

Aldamir was the second son of King Eldacar of Gondor and succeeded him
in TA 1490 because his elder brother Ornendil was executed by Castamir.
Aldamir's fifty year reign was marked with constant warfare with the
Corsairs of Umbar (among them were the sons of Castamir) and the
Haradrim. He was slain in battle with the Men of Harad and Corsairs of
Umbar in TA 1540 and was succeeded by his son Vinyarion.


Etymology

Aldamir was a Quenya word that meant 'Tree-jewel'.

name: Mauhúr
text:
MAUHÚR was an Uruk-hai of Isengard in the late Third Age during the War
of the Ring. Biography Mauhúr was sent to reinforce Uglúk and the
Uruk-hai Scouts as they returned to Isengard with Merry and Pippin. He
found them surrounded by Éomer's Rohirrim Éored at the edge of Fangorn
Forest, from which he led his Orcs in an attack. This attack was a
failure: the Rohirrim were able to defeat the Orcs, even with Mauhúr's
reinforcements. Though Mauhúr's own fate isn't known with absolute
certainty, it is assumed that he was among those killed at the hands of
the Rohirrim.

name: Morwë
text:
MORWË, along with Nurwë, refused the summons of the Valar to Aman.


Biography

Upon discovering the awakening of the Elves in Cuiviénen, the Vala Oromë
traveled back to Valinor to bring news. When Oromë returned to the
Elves, he invited them. Ingwë, Finwë, and Elwë served as their
ambassadors. The ambassadors returned three years later to persaude the
other Elves to come to Aman. Morwë and Nurwë refused the summons,
leading the Avari in Cuiviénen.


Etymology

The Quenyan _mor_ means (“black”) and the suffix _-wë_ occurs in many
names, though not exclusively masculine.

name: Belen
text:
BELEN was an Edain of the House of Bëor and Bëor's second son.


Biography

Belen's elder brother was Baran, and from him the great heroes of the
House of Bëor were descended, including Barahir and Beren. Bëor's
younger son left less of a mark on history, to the extent that he is not
even named in the published _The Silmarillion_. He does appear in other
accounts, though, where he is named as Belen. Belen's line was a little
less illustrious than his brother's: his most famous descendant was his
great-great-granddaughter Emeldir, who became the wife of Baran's
descendant Barahir.

name: Wulf
text:
WULF I was a Dunlending lord who, for a short period of time, ruled
Rohan.

Wulf was the son of Freca, who tried to force a wedding between Wulf and
the daughter of the King of Rohan, Helm Hammerhand. Helm killed his
father, and Wulf took charge of a Dunlending army that overran Rohan.

Wulf took Edoras, and besieged the Rohirrim at the Hornburg in the
refuge which would later be called Helm's Deep.

Wulf's Dunlending army managed to kill Helm Hammerhand as well as his
sons Haleth and Háma, but was in turn killed by Helm's nephew Fréaláf
Hildeson, who reclaimed Rohan for the Rohirrim.
titles: Lord of Dunland, King of Rohan (claimed & illegal)

name: Bain
text:
BAIN was a Man of Dale and the second King of the renewed Kingdom of
Dale.


Biography

Born in the year TA 2925 of the late Third Age, Bain was a man of Dale,
son to the famed Bard the Bowman. His rule may have been a peaceful and
uneventful one. It was during his time as King, after his father's
passing, that many party gifts of different varieties were ordered for
use at Bilbo's Farewell Birthday Party in TA 3001. Bain presumably died
in TA 3007, as that was when his son, Brand, became King. His son would
later fight in the War of the Ring at the Battle of Dale, where he was
slain.

name: Lugdush
text:
LUGDUSH was an Uruk-hai of Isengard.   Biography Lugdush was in the
service of Saruman and his army and a member of the Uruk-hai Scouts
commanded by Uglúk that captured Merry and Pippin beneath Amon Hen, and
drove them westwards towards Isengard. He was ordered by Uglúk to set a
guard around the halflings and not kill them unless their attackers
broke through. He was later slaughtered by the Rohirrim at Fangorn
forest, as were all the other Uruks and Orcs from Mordor that were
under Grishnákh's command. It was there that Lugdush met his end, at the
hands of Éomer's Rohirrim in _The Two Towers_.

name: Barahir (Steward)
text:
BARAHIR was the eighth Ruling Steward of Gondor.


Biography

Born in TA 2290, Barahir was the son of Hador. Following the death of
his father, Hador, in TA 2395 Barahir became the eighth Ruling Steward
of Gondor, and the eighth steward to rule during the era known as the
Watchful Peace. The realm during this time was relatively free of any
troubles. Barahir ruled Gondor for seventeen years until his death in TA
2412 at the age of 122 years old, and was succeeded by his son
Dior.


Etymology

In Sindarin, the name BARAHIR means “Fiery lord”, from _bara_ (“fiery,
eager”) and hîr (“master, lord”).

name: Aravir
text:
ARAVIR was the fourth Chieftain of the Dúnedain.


Biography

He was raised by Elrond in Rivendell while his father Aranuir dwelt in
the wild. At his father's death in TA 2247, Aravir in turn became the
Chieftain of the Dúnedain. During his rule the Watchful Peace slowly
came to an end as Sauron returned to the north-west of Middle-earth,
although his presence remained unknown.

Aravir died in TA 2319 after serving as Chieftain seventy-two years, and
was followed by his son Aragorn I.


Etymology

His name means “Noble Jewel”, from the Sindarin _ara_ (“king, noble”)
and _mir_ or _vir_ (“jewel”).

name: Narvi
text:
NARVI (fl. SA 750?) (originally NGARVI, ÑARVI) was a dwarf of
Khazad-dûm (Moria) during the Second Age.

He was probably of Durin's Folk.


Biography

Narvi is best known for making of the Doors of Durin for the West-gate
of Moria, on which Celebrimbor, an elf, wrote the inscription. He worked
closely with the Gwaith-i-Mírdain; Celebrimbor in particular was his
close friend. It can be implied that the relationship between Dwarves
and Elves was neither pivotal nor had it yet subsided; Other than the
age of the hall or the door, this also means Narvi lived during either
the Early Days or the First Age.

name: Andwise Roper
text:
ANDWISE ROPER also known as ANDY was a Hobbit of the Shire.


History

Andwise was the uncle of Samwise Gamgee. He was the first child of
Hobson Gamgee and Rowan Greenhand and was born in TA 2923 (SR 1323).
Andwise had three younger siblings - Halfred, May and Hamfast (the
father of Sam). Andwise was commonly known as Andy and had a son named
Anson, who was born in TA 2961.

Andwise and his father, Hobson, were both rope-makers and owned a
Rope-walk in the village of Tighfield. When Hobson Gamgee died in TA
2984, Andwise took over the rope-walk. He taught Samwise Gamgee some of
his knowledge of ropes.

name: Finglas
text:
FINGLAS (Sindarin for 'hair-leaf'), also known in Westron as LEAFLOCk,
was an Ent of Fangorn Forest. Finglas was one of three oldest Ents still
living during the end of the Third Age. He, Skinbark, and Treebeard were
the only ones left of the first and eldest of the Ents in Middle-earth.
By the time of the War of the Ring, Finglas had become sleepy and
“treeish” (dormant and inanimate, like a tree). He stood alone in a
meadow and dozed during the summer. At first he would awake in
wintertime, but eventually he remained in place year-round, preferring
to remain dormant to avoid the troubles of the world.

name: Gorgol
text:
GORGOL was an Orc chieftain, also called THE BUTCHER, who lived in
Beleriand during the First Age. Biography Gorgol was called “Butcher”
because of the many foes he “butchered”. He was the leader of the team
which slaughtered Barahir and his companions near Tarn Aeluin. He
claimed the famous Ring of Barahir, and later was slain by Beren who
took back his father's ring. Gorgol, holding the hand of Barahir aloft,
said that he was minded to keep the Ring and declare to Morgoth that the
hand of Barahir was bare. But at that moment Beren sprang into the camp,
slew Gorgol, and seized the hand, making his escape.

name: Handir
text:
HANDIR, son of Haldir was the second to last Chieftain of the Haladin
and a Lord of the Mannish settlements of the land of Brethil.


Biography

Handir was born sometime in the mid-fifth century of the First Age. He
was said to be a great warrior. His was chieftain and Lord of the Men of
Brethil around the time of the Nírnaeth Arnoediad. During the time of
his lordship, the Orcs invaded his lands and he led the fight against
them and he was slain in battle north of the Forest of Brethil, and his
people driven back into the woods. He was married to Beldis of the House
of Bëor and had one son called Brandir.
titles: Chieftain of the Haladin, Lord of Brethil

name: Berelach
text:
BERELACH was the only son of Borlas and had an unnamed older sister.


Biography

Berelach was a childhood friend of Saelon, who was caught by his father
Borlas and taken to his home for scolding. They had been constant
companion since then, though they seldom meet after Berelach was
stationed at Harlond, and then moved to Pelargir. Berelach told his
father about the “disappearing shipmen and small vessel at the
Fleet.”


Etymology

His name might be translated to the Sindarin _beren_ (“bold”) and
_lhach_ (" leaping flame").

Earlier Name

The earlier names for him were _Bergil_  and then later changed to
_Berthil_.

name: Angelica Baggins
text:
ANGELICA BAGGINS was a Hobbit of the Shire.


Biography

 Angelica was born in
TA 2981 (SR 1381). She was the daughter of Ponto Baggins II and the
grand-niece of Bilbo Baggins, and the granddaughter of Gilly Brownlock.
Angelica was young at the time of Bilbo's Farewell Birthday Party and
was noted for her vanity and considered her face to be quite shapely.
After the celebration, she received a round convex mirror as a gift
because she obviously admired her appearance. She apparently never
married.


Etymology

Like many Female hobbits, Angelica was named after a flower. The version
native to Britain is a perennial herb.

name: Angamaitë
text:
ANGAMAITË was the great-grandson of Castamir. Along with Sangahyando, he
became an important figure amongst the Haradrim and the Corsairs of
Umbar.


Biography

Angamaitë was a descendant of the rebel Castamir and carried on the
traditional hatred against Gondor. In TA 1634, King Minardil was at
Pelargir without fear of any attack. Angamaitë and Sangahyando soon
learned about this through spies and sacked the city, killing Minardil
and seizing great amounts of treasure.


Etymology

The name ANGAMAITË means “iron-handed”, from the Quenya word _anga_
(“iron”). Angamaitë was originally called ANGOMAITË in an earlier
text.

name: Náin II
text:
NÁIN II was a Dwarf of Durin's Folk and a King of Durin's Folk.


Biography

Náin was born in the Grey Mountains, and the son of Óin. He succeeded
his father in TA 2488. Under Náin II, the Dwarves lived peacefully in
the mountains but the time of the Watchful Peace had come to an end and
many dangers were growing from the West and North. During the final
years of his reign, the dragons came down from the northern wastes and
began to make war upon the Dwarves. Náin was 247 years old when he died.
He was succeeded by his son, Dáin I. He had a younger son Borin, from
whom several of Thorin Oakenshield's companions were descended.

name: Aratan
text:
ARATAN was the second son of Isildur.


Biography

Aratan did not take part in the invasion of Mordor or the Siege of
Barad-dûr. Instead, his father sent he and his brother Ciryon to Minas
Ithil with a force in case Sauron should break or escape the siege
through Cirith Dúath, and assail the Dúnedain before he was yet
defeated. He like his brothers Elendur and Ciryon, were slain at the
Gladden Fields.


Etymology

_Aratan_ translates from the High-Elven tongue (Quenya) into the Common
Speech as “Royal Man”. The second element in the name, _atan_, is the
root of _Atani_, the ancient, Quenyan word referring to the whole race
of Man.

name: Aravorn
text:
ARAVORN was the ninth Chieftain of the Dúnedain.


Biography

Like his forefathers, Aravorn was raised by Elrond Half-elven in
Rivendell. Aravorn became the Chieftain of the Dúnedain in the year TA
2588 at the death of his father. During Aravorn's rule, the Orc and Wolf
attacks continued as the strength of the Dark Lord Sauron slowly began
to increase. Aravorn died in the year TA 2654 after serving as chieftain
for sixty-six years, and was followed by his son Arahad II.


Etymology

In Sindarin, the name ARAVORN has unclear origins. It is composed of the
words _aran_ (“king”) and _morn_ (“darkness, black”), which is later
lenited to _vorn_.

name: Ulfang
text:
ULFANG, also known as ULFANG THE BLACK, was the Easterling chieftain of
the First Age who followed Caranthir to the Nirnaeth Arnoediad, but
betrayed the Sons of Fëanor and gave Morgoth victory.


Biography

Ulfang was one of the Swarthy Men who had come out of the east into
Beleriand. He sided with Caranthir's forces at the beginning of the
Nírnaeth Arnoediad. During the battle his men turned on the Sons of
Fëanor. Their force, which was being attacked on three sides, was
dissipated, allowing Morgoth to concentrate his forces on Fingon and
Turgon. Ulfang, however, paid for his treachery with his life, as did
his sons Ulfast, Ulwarth, and Uldor.

name: Fram
text:
FRAM was the son of Frumgar and the fourth Lord of the Éothéod.


Biography

Fram and his people lived in the far northern part of the Wilderland
just below the Grey Mountains in mid-Third Age. He was most famous for
slaying the evil worm Scatha, a Cold-drake, in TA 2000. Afterwards he
claimed the Dragon's treasure horde which the Dwarves believed
rightfully belonged to them. Knowing this, he sent back to them a
necklace made from the teeth of Scatha along with a message that the
Dwarves found insulting. This may have started a war between the two
peoples that may have been Fram's demise.

He may have also founded the Éothéod capital of Framsburg.

name: Ar-Sakalthôr
text:
AR-SAKALTHÔR was the twenty-second King of Númenor.


Biography

Ar-Sakalthôr followed the royal tradition of turning away from the ways
of the Valar. He succeeded his father Ar-Zimrathôn as King, ruling
Númenor for sixty-nine years, and was succeeded by his son, Ar-Gimilzôr.
The traditional Quenya version of his name was “Tar-Falassion”.

Ar-Sakalthôr died in SA 3102, living to the age of two-hundred and
twenty-six. He ruled Númenor for sixty-nine years and was succeeded by
his son, Ar-Gimilzôr.


Etymology

_FALASSION_ means “Shore-son” or “Child of the Shore” from the Quenya
_falassë_ (“shore”) and _-ion_ (a patronymic ending, “son of,
descendant”).

name: Forhend
text:
'''Forhend '''was a Man of Brethil, and a guard of the Crossings of
Teiglin, in the First Age.


Biography

Forhend was one of the guards under the command of Manthor who came
across weary Húrin in Haudh-en-Elleth, immediately after the events
recounted in _The Children of Húrin._ When Manthor, who recognized
Húrin, left towards Obel Halad (the Hall of the Haladin) to assist Húrin
in his errand, he took only him and Forhend along. The others of the
Guard, such as Sagroth and Avranc, were to stay behind.

It is possible that Forhend was of some familial relation to Forweg, one
of the outlaws encountered earlier by Túrin Turambar in lands near to
Brethil.

name: Milo Burrows
text:
MILO BURROWS was a Hobbit of the Shire.


Biography

Milo married into the Baggins family when he married a distant cousin of
Bilbo and Frodo named Peony. Together they had four children, most of
which were at Bilbo's Farewell Birthday Party; they were Mosco, Moro,
Myrtle, and Minto.

Milo was known for his habit of failing to reply to letters, and because
of this he was one of those that found a specially marked gift, a golden
inkpot and pen, waiting for him in Bag End, after Bilbo's
departure.


Appearance in adaptations

Video games

-   Milo Burrows was voiced by Michael Reisz in The Lord of the Rings:
    The Fellowship of the Ring (video game) in 2002.

name: Belecthor I
text:
BELECTHOR I was the fifteenth Ruling Steward of Gondor.


Biography

Born in TA 2545, Belecthor I was the son of Húrin II. Belecthor I
succeeded his father as Steward in TA 2628. The Corsairs of Umbar were
the major threat to Gondor at the time, although no major events are
recorded. Other than minor skirmishes no events are recorded during his
reign. Belecthor had two children: Morwen, a daughter, and Orodreth.
Belecthor I died in TA 2655 at the age of 110 years old after a rule of
twenty-seven years. He was followed by his son Orodreth.


Etymology

The name BELECTHOR might mean “Mighty eagle”, from the Sindarin words
_beleg_ (“mighty”) and _thor(on)_ (“eagle”).

name: Bungo Baggins
text:
BUNGO BAGGINS was a Hobbit of the Shire and the father of Bilbo.


Biography

Bungo was born in TA 2846. He was the eldest of the five children of
Mungo and Laura (Grubb) Baggins. His siblings were named Belba, Longo,
Linda, and Bingo. Bungo married Belladonna Took sometime in S.R. 1280
and built a luxurious Hobbit-hole called Bag End in the Hill at Hobbiton
for her. They had one child, Bilbo, who was born in TA 2890. Bungo died
in TA 2926.


Legacy

Aside from fathering Bilbo, Bungo is most remembered for the
construction of the famous Bag End, which had become a topic of great
discussion and a place of important meetings and gatherings concerning
the world.


Quotes

name: Azaghâl
text:
AZAGHÂL was the King of the Broadbeam Dwarves, one of the seven Dwarf
clans, and Lord of the Dwarven realm of Belegost in the Blue Mountains
during the First Age.


Biography

The Dragon-helm of Dor-lómin was originally made for him by Telchar the
smith of Nogrod. Azaghâl had given the helm to Maedhros after he saved
his life when Azaghâl was waylaid by Orcs upon the Dwarf-Road in East
Beleriand.



He was slain by the Dragon Glaurung after severely wounding him during
the Nirnaeth Arnoediad. After his death, his kin bore him away from the
battlefield ignoring the rest of their enemies and singing a frightening
dirge that allowed them to leave without further incident.
titles: Lord of Belegost, King of the Broadbeams

name: Amaranth Brandybuck
text:
AMARANTH BRANDYBUCK was a Hobbit of the Shire.


Biography

Amaranth was born in TA 2904 (SR 1304) to Mirabella Took and Gorbadoc
Brandybuck. Amaranth's older brother, Rory, was the grandfather of
Meriadoc Brandybuck. She also had five younger siblings, one of which,
Primula, was the mother of Frodo Baggins. Her other siblings were
Saradas, Dodinas, Asphodel, and Dinodas. Amaranth Brandybuck died in TA
2998 (SR 1398).


Name

An Amaranth is a poetic term for a flower that never withers. It is also
the name of a family of 60-70 plants found all over the globe. Amaranth
is used as a food source and in ornamental gardens. Certain members of
this family are considered weeds.

name: Beleg of Arnor
text:
BELEG was the second King of Arthedain.


Biography

Beleg was the son and heir of King Amlaith of Arthedain and came to the
throne in TA 946 at the death of his father. During his reign, Hobbits
were first seen west of the Misty Mountains, entering Eriador. Most of
them were Harfoots. Also during his reign Sauron returned to Mirkwood,
his first return to Middle-earth since the end of the Second Age.

Beleg died in TA 1029 at the age of two-hundred and eighteen after
ruling for eighty-three years and was succeeded by his son Mallor.


Etymology

He shares a name with Beleg Cúthalion, the famous Sindarin bowman of
Doriath and friend of Túrin Turambar. The name means 'mighty'.

name: Araglas
text:
ARAGLAS was the sixth Chieftain of the Dúnedain.


Biography

Like his forefathers, Araglas was raised by Elrond in Rivendell while
his father Aragorn I dwelt in the wild. Aragorn was killed by a pack of
wild wolves in TA 2327, and Araglas succeed him as Chieftain of the
Dúnedain while still very young by the reckoning of his people. He died
in TA 2455 after 128 years as chieftain and was succeeded by his son
Arahad I.


Etymology

ARAGLAS is a Sindarin name that means “Royal Leaf”, from the words _ara_
(“king, noble, royal”) and _lass_ (“leaf”).


Behind the Scenes

Arallas was a former name until it was corrected on a later page of
J.R.R. Tolkien's manuscript on the subject.

name: Khîm
text:
KHÎM was a Petty-dwarf, was the son of Mîm and brother of Ibûn.
Biography He, his father, and his brother Ibûn were the last of the
Petty-dwarves in Middle-earth. He was struck by an arrow fired by a
member of Túrin's outlaw band when he and his family were set upon near
their home at Amon Rûdh. Khîm escaped the attack but died of his wounds
at Amon Rûdh before his father returned with Túrin and his men. Túrin
promised to pay Mîm a ransom to atone for Khîm's death, and this was in
part the source of Amon Rûdh's other name, the House of Ransom. Mîm
cursed Khîm's killer, Andróg, forcing Andróg to break his bow.
Refenrences - de:Khîm es:Khîm fr:Khîm it:Khîm nl:Khîm pl:Khîm ru:Кхим

name: Amdír
text:
AMDÍR, also known as MALGALAD, was an Elf of Doriath, the father of
Amroth and King of Lothlórien.


Biography

Amdír was a Sindarin elf from Doriath who left east into Eriador after
the War of Wrath. He took over the realm of Lórinand (later Lórien) from
the Silvan Elves who had had no lords before, south of where Oropher
established the Woodland Realm among the Silvan Elves of Mirkwood.

Amdír and Oropher joined Gil-galad's forces when he crossed the Misty
Mountains and took the help of the Longbeards of Moria in the War of the
Last Alliance of Elves and Men. He was killed in the Battle of Dagorlad
alongside most of those who followed him. His son Amroth succeeded him
as King of Lórien.
birth: Sometime during Years of the Trees or the First Age ?

name: Belegund
text:
BELEGUND was a Edain and a Man of Dorthonion and one of Barahir's
Outlaws.


Biography

Belegund was a son of Bregolas born in Dorthonion in the late First Age.
He was the father of Rían, and thus the grandfather of Tuor. He is also
the great uncle of Túrin. He was among the many Men of Dorthonion that
went to war in the Dagor Bragollach. After the defeat, Belegund remained
with Barahir and his armed band of men refused to surrender or submit to
the will of Morgoth, thus they were declared outlaws and hunted to the
death. He and the others survived for nearly five years. The outlaw band
were eventually betrayed to Sauron by the unhappy Gorlim and he and his
company were killed at Tarn Aeluin by Orcs.

name: Amarië
text:
AMARIË was a Vanyar Elf of Valinor in Aman.


Biography

Amarië did not follow her love, Finrod, in his journey to Middle-earth.
She and Finrod were betrothed, but he never married while in
Middle-earth. It is noted in the Lay of Leithian that Finrod was soon
allowed to return to life in Valinor and “now dwells with Amarië”, so
they probably were wed later - but there is no such information in _The
Silmarillion_.


Etymology

The meaning of the name _AMARIË_ is unclear. It is possible her name
came from the Quenyan word MÁR, meaning “home”, perhaps referring to her
home in Aman. It is also possible that her name originated from the
Quenyan words MÁRA, meaning “good”, and IEN, which is a feminine ending.

name: Angbor
text:
ANGBOR was a Man of Gondor and the Lord of Lamedon at the end of the
Third Age and beginning of the Fourth Age.


Biography

During the last months of the War of the Ring, Angbor was met by Aragorn
when the latter arrived from the Paths of the Dead. He was in battle
with the Corsairs of Umbar, when the Army of the Dead gave their aid.
Angbor was the only man who had courage enough to meet with Aragorn, who
instructed him to gather his men and ride to the aid of Minas Tirith. It
was later mentioned that he and his men arrived at Minas Tirith during
the time Aragorn and company left for the Black Gate. It was Aragorn who
named Angbor “the Fearless”.


Etymology

_Angbor_ is a Sindarin word meaning “iron fist”.

name: Anardil
text:
ANARDIL was the sixth King of Gondor.


Biography

Anardil was born in TA 136. He ascended to the throne after the death
of his father Eärendil in TA 324. No notable events were recorded for
his reign, except that he was the last king to dwell in Osgiliath during
the summer, as his son rebuilt and expanded Minas Anor. Anardil died in
TA 411 aged 275 after a rule of eighty-seven years and was succeeded by
his son Ostoher.


Etymology

The name ANARDIL is a Quenyan word that meant “devoted to the sun” or
“friend of the sun”. It is made from the words ANAR, meaning “sun”, and
-DIL (another form of the more common ending -NDIL), meaning “devoted”
or “friend”. A much earlier Anardil was the birth-name of TAR-ALDARION.

name: Anborn
text:
ANBORN was a Man of Gondor and a scout for the Rangers of Ithilien, and
was also Faramir's deputy.


Biography

On March 7, TA 3019, Anborn reported to his captain, Faramir, that he
had seen a strange creature scurry up a tree and also hissed at him.
Anborn theorized that it might have been a large squirrel of Mirkwood,
although he didn't think that possibility was likely, as the creature he
saw was black and had no tail. However, under law of Gondor that no
animal of Ithilien should be harmed for any reason, Anborn left the
creature alone.
It was also Anborn who spotted the same creature, Gollum, in the
Forbidden Pool, and then reported it to Faramir at once.


Appearance

-   _The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers_

name: Aragost
text:
ARAGOST was the eighth Chieftain of the Dúnedain.


Biography

Like his forefathers, Aragost was raised by Elrond in Rivendell while
his father Arahad I dwelt in the wild. He became the Chieftain of the
Dúnedain in TA 2523 at the death of his father. His rule was an
uneventful one, as the attention of the enemy was focused on Gondor,
where the Éothéod had settled the new realm of Rohan.

He died in TA 2588, after serving as chieftain for sixty-five years
and was followed by his son Aravorn.


Etymology

In Sindarin, ARAGOST means “Royal Dread”, from _ara_ (“king, noble,
royal”) and _gost_ (“dread”).


Behind the Scenes

Arandost was a former name until it was corrected on a later page of
J.R.R. Tolkien's manuscript on the subject.

name: Òmar
text:
ÒMAR also known as AMILLO was a Valar in the earlier forms of the
legendarium. Biography Òmar was youngest of the Valar and the brother of
Salmar when he entered into the world lastly. He was a master of
languages and knew all tongues and sang great songs for all to hear. He
was known to be singing and trilling in the gardens of Oromë near the
Woods of Oromë where Nielíqui, the daughter of Oromë and Vána danced. He
was later involved in the decision to capture Melko and participated in
the war with his brother Salmar and the other Valar. When the Elves
later came to the Aman, the Teleri learned much of song from him. When
darkness fell upon Aman, he spoke of the “lamentation of Vána” referring
to her sadness over the loss of Laurelin.

name: Aragorn I
text:
ARAGORN I was the fifth Chieftain of the Dúnedain.


Biography

Aragorn was the son of Aravir. When the North Kingdom of the Dúnedain
was destroyed by the Witch-king of Angmar in TA 1974, the heirs to this
kingdom were then called Dúnedain chieftains and there were sixteen of
them. There is little known about Aragorn I, other than the fact that he
was the fifth chieftain and was slain by wolves in Eriador in TA 2327. 

He served as chieftain for only eight years but lived for one-hundred
years and was succeeded by his son Araglas.

Aragorn II, later Elessar, the first King of the Reunited Kingdom, was
named after his forefather.


Etymology

The name Aragorn means “Revered King”, from the Sindarin ara (“king”)
and (n)gorn (“revered”).

name: Arahad II
text:
ARAHAD II was the tenth Chieftain of the Dúnedain.


Biography

Like his forefathers, Arahad was raised by Elrond in Rivendell while his
father Aravorn dwelt in the wild. He became the Chieftain of the
Dúnedain in TA 2654 at the death of his father. During his rule the
Hobbits of the Shire prospered under the protection of the Rangers, and
the first pipe-weed was planted in the Shire's Southfarthing. In the
Shire, Isengrim II became the Thain and began digging the Great Smials.
Arahad died in TA 2719 after serving as chieftain for sixty-five
years, and was followed by his son Arassuil.


Etymology

Arahad was named for his great grandfather, Arahad I. His name is a
Sindarin name that is composed of _ara_ (“king, noble”) and _had_
(“hurl, throw”).

name: Dimtilion
text:
DIMTILION was a Silvan Elf who served the Galadhrim Warriors that
defended Lothlórien's borders.


Biography

During the War of the Ring, Dimtilion was one hundreds of Silvan Elves
that followed Haldir to Helm's Deep and provide their support and aid to
the people of Rohan and their king from the terrible atrocities that
Saruman, who betrayed the White Council and became a servant of the Dark
Lord Sauron. Stationed at the Deeping Wall with all of his kin,
Dimtilion demonstrated his skills as an archer and killed a large number
of Uruk-hai that were climbing the wall. As he kept on fighting to
defend Rohan's people, Dimtilion was slain in the battle, but he would
be remembered of those that gave their lives in defending Rohan from the
armies of Isengard.

name: Grimbeorn
text:
GRIMBEORN, also known as GRIMBEORN THE OLD, was Beorn's son.


Biography

Grimbeorn's date of birth is unknown, but it was probably within the
first few decades following the Battle of Five Armies in TA 2941. Like
his father, he could turn into the shape of a bear, and he lived in the
same regions as his father had in the Vales of Anduin. He took over as
chieftain of the Beornings after his father's death. By the time of the
Council of Elrond he was known as Grimbeorn the Old. As chieftain, he
kept the High Pass and the Ford of Carrock free from Orcs and Wolves,
though Glóin commented to Frodo Baggins that his “tolls are high” and he
was “not over fond of Dwarves.” He was the chieftain of many stout Men
and had some military power in the Vales of Anduin.
birth: Unknown, probably several years or so after the Battle of Five Armies

name: Black Serpent
text:
The BLACK SERPENT was a Haradrim chieftain during the War of the Ring.

His banner was a black serpent upon scarlet.


Biography

The Black Serpent led a large force of what appeared to be mainly
cavalry in the invasion of Gondor in support of their Mordor allies. At
the time of the Rohirrim's arrival, he was in the southern part of the
Pelennor Fields with a large force. He spotted the banner of King
Théoden. Filled with a great wrath, he and his men drew their swords
feeling that they could defeat what appeared to be only a small group.
When Rohirrim came, they fell upon them with a great fury and then
Théoden himself faced him and threw him down with great strength and
slew him. Then, his remaining force seeing all that they had lost fled
away in fear.
birth: YT ? during the Noontide of Valinor

name: Forthwini
text:
FORTHWINI was the son of Marhwini and the second Lord of the Éothéod.


Biography

Like his father before him, Forthwini lived in troubled times with all
the lands east of the Misty Mountains still in danger of invasion from
the tribes of the Easterlings. Certain that they were rearming for war,
he went to King Ondoher of Gondor with a warning of this and soon they
prepared for war. The Éothéod joined them and came to the aid of the
Northern Army near the Black Gate but they were defeated and the Éothéod
retreated. The battle claimed the lives of Ondoher and his two sons but
the Southern Army won and the Easterlings were defeated. Forthwini's
fate is unknown but as he was Lord of the Éothéod it is possible that he
accompanied them to the battle and was slain.

name: Arathorn II
text:
ARATHORN II was the fifteenth Chieftain of the Dúnedain and father of
the future Heir of Isildur, Aragorn II Elessar.


Biography

Like his forefathers, he was raised by Elrond in Rivendell while his
father Arador dwelt in the wild. Arathorn asked for the hand of Gilraen
at a very young age. Though her father Dírhael initially opposed the
marriage, his wife prevailed upon him to agree to the match, as she
foresaw that an early death awaited Arathorn.

Arathorn became the Chieftain of the Dúnedain in TA 2930, when his
father was captured by Hill-trolls. He ruled for only three years until
TA 2933, when he was slain by an arrow that pierced his eye while
hunting Orcs with Elladan and Elrohir. He was followed by his infant son
Aragorn, also known as Elessar Telcontar.
titles: Chieftain of the Dúnedain, Heir of Isildur

name: Sangahyando
text:
SANGAHYANDO was the great-grandson of Castamir of Gondor and along with
Angamaitë, he became an important figure amongst the Haradrim and the
Corsairs of Umbar.


Biography

Sangahyando, like Angamaitë, was probably born in Umbar to an unnamed
mother and father. As descendants of the rebel Castamir, they carried on
the traditional hatred against Gondor. In TA 1634, when King Minardil
was at Pelargir, spies of Sangahyndo and Angamaitë told them about the
king's visit to Pelargir. Soon they raided the city, killed the king and
seized the great amounts of treasures laying about in the city. His
ultimate fate is unknown.


Etymology and Names

_Sangahyando_ was a Quenya word that meant 'throng-cleaver'. Sangahyando
was originally called “Sangahyanda” in an earlier text.

name: Almarian
text:
ALMARIAN was a royal Númenórean woman and Queen of Númenor during the
early Second Age.


Biography

Almarian was the daughter of a Númenórean sailor Vëantur, the Captain of
the King's Ships under Tar-Elendil. She was married to Tar-Meneldur and
she was mother of Aldarion, the future Tar-Aldarion, the sixth King of
Númenor.

She cared little for ships and the sea, though her father was a great
sailor. She married and gave birth to a son, Aldarion, and he soon
desired to follow in the footsteps of her father Vëantur which later
displeased his father, who wanted him to marry and settle down. However,
Almarian supported her son in everything he did and later served as a
mediator between her husband and his son on the matters regarding his
life choices.

She was a woman of exceptional beauty.
birth: YT ? during the Noontide of Valinor

name: Celebrindor
text:
CELEBRINDOR was the fifth King of Arthedain.


Biography

Celebrindor was the son of King Celepharn of Arthedain. He came to the
throne in TA 1191 at the death of his father. During Celebrindor's rule
over Arthedain, there was peace between relations with the other
splinter-realms of Arnor, Cardolan and Rhudaur and therefore his reign
was an uneventful one, and no evil threatened the realm as of yet.
Celebrindor died in TA 1272 after ruling for eighty-one years and was
succeeded by his son Malvegil.


Etymology

_CELEBRINDOR_ was a Sindarin name that probably meant 'silverlord' or
'silverlike lord'.

Former names

As outlined in _The Peoples of Middle-earth_: The Heirs of Elendil,
Celebrindor was first written as _Celemenegil_ and _Celebrindol_ but was
corrected and changed to Celebrindor.

name: Grór
text:
GRÓR was the founder of the Dwarven realm in the Iron Hills and its
first lord.


Biography

Grór was born in Grey Mountains as the youngest of three sons born to
Dáin I. His older brothers were Thrór and Frór. After the death of his
father in TA 2589, he and his brother left the Grey Mountains and while
Thrór went back to the Lonely Mountain, Grór went further into the east
and in TA 2590 he established the Kingdom of the Dwarves in the Iron
